Rationale
Roll Forward
Blurb
Overview
This module will provide students with an understanding of the processes required for the successful planning and delivery of research projects. It will also Introduce students to the latest, cutting edge technologies in their research field of interest. It will develop in students the transferrable communication skills that will enable them to disseminate their findings to both scientific and general audiences. Learning materials will be made available on CANVAS, recognizing levels of prior knowledge, and through provision within lectures and tutorial discussions. Each topic is introduced through a lecture which develops learning and through in-built formative feedback and advised supplemental reading as required.
Educational Aims
This module is designed to:

Provide students with an understanding of the processes required for the successful planning and delivery of research projects;

Introduce students to the latest, cutting edge technologies in their research field of interest;

Develop in students the transferrable communication skills that will enable them to disseminate their findings to both scientific and general audiences.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module will provide students with an understanding of the processes and methods required for the successful planning and delivery of research projects. It will also Introduce students to the latest, cutting edge technologies that will support their research field of interest. It will develop in students the transferrable communication skills that will enable them to disseminate their findings to both scientific and general audiences.
Outline Syllabus
Core components:

Experimental design and hypothesis testing;
Research Ethics and aspects of obtaining Research Ethics approval;
Popular science writing and public understanding of science via News and Views writing
Meta analysis;
Model species;
Observational sampling;
Transcriptomics and arrays;
Proteomics;

Optional components (students choose 2 from an either or from 4 topics, with guidance from project supervisor). Topics include:

- Genomic technologies or Ecology mathematical modelling;
- Molecular ecology or Advanced microscopic techniques

Students must also attend (and write a brief report on) at least 5 seminars presented within their host department, institute or University or an online resource (currently HLS
Teaching and Learning Methods
The teaching and learning strategy has been guided by the Curriculum 2021 Framework attributes and hallmarks, particularly global citizenship and research connected teaching. Students will be dealing with topics of utmost importance for their professional development and taught by active researchers in this field.
Teaching Method 1 – Lecture Description: A series of 12 lectures covering skills and applications in biological sciences will be delivered asynchronously via Teams.
Teaching Method 2 – Seminar Description: Students will view seminars presented online by external or university staff that communicate scientific advances and current progress, with and brief reports used to appraise their journalistic communication skills.
Teaching Method 3 – small group tutorials for discussion of ethical topics

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
Assessment strategy has been guided by the Curriculum 2021 Framework attributes and hallmarks, particularly authentic assessments. The module runs across both semesters. The plan is to change the module to be online to match its sister module Life631 that is used for off-campus MBioSci students.

The previous assessments will all run but in this COVID era

1) News & Views summative assessment – scheduled lecture session followed by timetabled and asynchronous opportunities for face-to-face discussion of the set task in the week after setting.

2) Ethics dissertation summative assessment - will have group tutorials of 20 students to discuss ethical issues pertinent to a subsequent dissertation with a staff member orchestrating the student-led discussion. Word count of dissertation is 1500 words +/- 10%.

3) Poster summative assessment – lecture session followed by independent study with students. Scheduled drop-in asynchronous Teams sessions will be set up for questions/discussion by the staff members.

4) Presentation summative assessment – block sessions will have groups of students all in attendance and taking turns to present (or when needed share screen) to give their talks to the group while assessment is made by the staff member. Groups will be sized based on choice of topic and maintaining a defined session time e.g. 2 h

5) An online zero-rated ‘attendance’ linked assessment will run as previous.

There is a reassessment opportunity that takes the form of assignments of the types described above. It will take place in the normal reassessment window and be capped at 50%.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Admin
Marked for Rollover
No
Replace Future Instances
No
Notes
LIFE731 will host learning materials online using CANVAS and there are scheduled in-person group tutorial sessions on campus to support assessments and a campus presentation session with peers as an audience.
LIFE731 has flexibility to run quite similar to the existing LIFE631 online only module in certain circumstances and as occurred during the COVID-19 pandemic.
This module is due to commence in September 2021. Updates included housekeeping, the addition of an overview, C2021 attributes and hallmarks to the assessment strategy and T&L methods. Clarification is added regarding options in the module for students with more molecular or more ecology based programme areas

 LocationPeriodCode 
 
Liverpool campus

Outcomes
Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Develop hypotheses and design a series of experiments that would allow these hypotheses to be tested
 LO2 Critically review the legal and moral frameworks within which scientific research must be conducted, in particular research ethics and current legislation;
 LO3 Effectively communicate research findings using writing styles for different audiences, including the scientific and lay communities, and to understand the need to promote the public understanding of science;
 LO4 Debate why and when biologists need to engage with mathematicians, computer scientists and physical scientists to obtain more quantitative, holistic or systems-based approaches to studying biological processes
 LO5 Critically review the latest scientific discoveries in their research field, and understand the principles underpinning cutting edge technologies that may be applied to their area of scientific investigation;
 LO6 Synthesise information, critically review evidence to support conclusions, and define complex problems by applying appropriate knowledge and skills.
Skills
 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Communication Skills
 S2 Organisational Skills
 S3 Lifelong learning skills
 S4 Problem solving/ critical thinking/ creativity analysing facts and situations and applying creative thinking to develop appropriate solutions.
 S5 Global perspectives demonstrate international perspectives as professionals/citizens; locate, discuss, analyse, evaluate information from international sources; consider issues from a variety of cultural perspectives, consider ethical and social responsibility issues in international settings; value diversity of language and culture

Rationale

Blurb
Overview
This module will provide students with an understanding of the processes required for the successful planning and delivery of research projects. It will also Introduce students to the latest, cutting edge technologies in their research field of interest. It will develop in students the transferrable communication skills that will enable them to disseminate their findings to both scientific and general audiences. Learning materials will be made available on CANVAS, recognizing levels of prior knowledge, and through provision within lectures and tutorial discussions. Each topic is introduced through a lecture which develops learning and through in-built formative feedback and advised supplemental reading as required.
Educational Aims
This module is designed to:

Provide students with an understanding of the processes required for the successful planning and delivery of research projects;

Introduce students to the latest, cutting edge technologies in their research field of interest;

Develop in students the transferrable communication skills that will enable them to disseminate their findings to both scientific and general audiences.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module will provide students with an understanding of the processes and methods required for the successful planning and delivery of research projects. It will also Introduce students to the latest, cutting edge technologies that will support their research field of interest. It will develop in students the transferrable communication skills that will enable them to disseminate their findings to both scientific and general audiences.
Outline Syllabus
Core components:

Experimental design and hypothesis testing;
Research Ethics and aspects of obtaining Research Ethics approval;
Popular science writing and public understanding of science via News and Views writing
Meta analysis;
Model species;
Observational sampling;
Transcriptomics and arrays;
Proteomics;

Optional components (students choose 2 from an either or from 4 topics, with guidance from project supervisor). Topics include:

- Genomic technologies or Ecology mathematical modelling;
- Molecular ecology or Advanced microscopic techniques

Students must also attend (and write a brief report on) at least 5 seminars presented within their host department, institute or University or an online resource (currently HLS
Teaching and Learning Methods
The teaching and learning strategy has been guided by the Curriculum 2021 Framework attributes and hallmarks, particularly global citizenship and research connected teaching. Students will be dealing with topics of utmost importance for their professional development and taught by active researchers in this field.
Teaching Method 1 – Lecture Description: A series of 12 lectures covering skills and applications in biological sciences will be delivered asynchronously via Teams.
Teaching Method 2 – Seminar Description: Students will view seminars presented online by external or university staff that communicate scientific advances and current progress, with and brief reports used to appraise their journalistic communication skills.
Teaching Method 3 – small group tutorials for discussion of ethical topics

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
Assessment strategy has been guided by the Curriculum 2021 Framework attributes and hallmarks, particularly authentic assessments. The module runs across both semesters. The plan is to change the module to be online to match its sister module Life631 that is used for off-campus MBioSci students.

The previous assessments will all run but in this COVID era

1) News & Views summative assessment – scheduled lecture session followed by timetabled and asynchronous opportunities for face-to-face discussion of the set task in the week after setting.

2) Ethics dissertation summative assessment - will have group tutorials of 20 students to discuss ethical issues pertinent to a subsequent dissertation with a staff member orchestrating the student-led discussion. Word count of dissertation is 1500 words +/- 10%.

3) Poster summative assessment – lecture session followed by independent study with students. Scheduled drop-in asynchronous Teams sessions will be set up for questions/discussion by the staff members.

4) Presentation summative assessment – block sessions will have groups of students all in attendance and taking turns to present (or when needed share screen) to give their talks to the group while assessment is made by the staff member. Groups will be sized based on choice of topic and maintaining a defined session time e.g. 2 h

5) An online zero-rated ‘attendance’ linked assessment will run as previous.

There is a reassessment opportunity that takes the form of assignments of the types described above. It will take place in the normal reassessment window and be capped at 50%.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Admin
Marked for Rollover
No
Replace Future Instances
No
Notes
LIFE731 will host learning materials online using CANVAS and there are scheduled in-person group tutorial sessions on campus to support assessments and a campus presentation session with peers as an audience.
LIFE731 has flexibility to run quite similar to the existing LIFE631 online only module in certain circumstances and as occurred during the COVID-19 pandemic.
This module is due to commence in September 2021. Updates included housekeeping, the addition of an overview, C2021 attributes and hallmarks to the assessment strategy and T&L methods. Clarification is added regarding options in the module for students with more molecular or more ecology based programme areas

 LocationPeriodCode

Main


Outcomes
Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Develop hypotheses and design a series of experiments that would allow these hypotheses to be tested
 LO2 Critically review the legal and moral frameworks within which scientific research must be conducted, in particular research ethics and current legislation;
 LO3 Effectively communicate research findings using writing styles for different audiences, including the scientific and lay communities, and to understand the need to promote the public understanding of science;
 LO4 Debate why and when biologists need to engage with mathematicians, computer scientists and physical scientists to obtain more quantitative, holistic or systems-based approaches to studying biological processes
 LO5 Critically review the latest scientific discoveries in their research field, and understand the principles underpinning cutting edge technologies that may be applied to their area of scientific investigation;
 LO6 Synthesise information, critically review evidence to support conclusions, and define complex problems by applying appropriate knowledge and skills.
Skills
 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Communication Skills
 S2 Organisational Skills
 S3 Lifelong learning skills
 S4 Problem solving/ critical thinking/ creativity analysing facts and situations and applying creative thinking to develop appropriate solutions.
 S5 Global perspectives demonstrate international perspectives as professionals/citizens; locate, discuss, analyse, evaluate information from international sources; consider issues from a variety of cultural perspectives, consider ethical and social responsibility issues in international settings; value diversity of language and culture
